message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest age-related macular degeneration (AMD), which can cause choroidal neovascularization. The most likely treatment is an anti-VEGF injection, which inhibits choroidal neovascularization. Options A and B are treatments for glaucoma and keratoconus, respectively, which are not indicated based on the patient’s symptoms. Option D is a treatment for retinal detachment, which is also not indicated based on the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest macular degeneration, and the treatment described is most likely an intravitreal injection of an anti-VEGF agent, which inhibits choroidal neovascularization. The other options are not relevant to the treatment of macular degeneration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest age-related macular degeneration (AMD), and the treatment for it involves intravitreal injections of anti–vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) agents, which inhibit choroidal neovascularization. The other options are used for different conditions such as glaucoma, keratoconus, and retinal detachment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of central vision loss and wavy distortions suggests choroidal neovascularization, which can be treated with intravitreal injections that inhibit it. Option A is used to treat glaucoma by decreasing intraocular pressure. Option B is used in corneal collagen crosslinking to treat keratoconus. Option D is a surgical technique to repair retinal detachment.

The symptoms described suggest age-related macular degeneration, which is commonly treated with anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) medications that inhibit choroidal neovascularization. The other options do not address the specific pathology of age-related macular degeneration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest age-related macular degeneration, which is often treated with intravitreal injections of anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) medications to inhibit choroidal neovascularization. Options A and B are related to glaucoma and corneal diseases, respectively, and Option D is a surgical procedure for retinal detachment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the symptoms, the patient may have age-related macular degeneration. Intravitreal injections of medication that inhibits choroidal neovascularization are commonly used to treat this condition by preventing the growth of new blood vessels that can cause further damage to the retina. Option A refers to treatments for glaucoma, option B is a treatment for keratoconus, and option D is a surgical procedure used to repair a retinal detachment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest age-related macular degeneration, and intravitreal injections of an anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) medication are commonly used to inhibit choroidal neovascularization, which is a cause of macular degeneration. Option A and option B refer to treatments for glaucoma and keratoconus, respectively, which are not related to macular degeneration. Option D refers to a treatment for retinal detachment, which is also not related to macular degeneration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms point towards age-related macular degeneration (AMD), and intravitreal injections of medications are commonly used for AMD. Among the options, only inhibiting choroidal neovascularization is a mechanism of action for medications used to treat AMD. Option A refers to treatments for glaucoma, option B refers to treatments for corneal ectasia, and option D refers to a surgical procedure for retinal detachment.
